The health of that digestion—as well as other things like mood and immunity—depends heavily on a teeming microflora of both beneficial and harmful bacteria that live in the lining of your GI tract <https://www.nm.org/healthbeat/healthy-tips/7-reasons-to-listen-to-your-gut>.\n\nBacteria often get a bad rap as germs that cause sickness. 2024-11-08 06:44:24,752: ObserveEventsHandler(  179): MEASUREMENT: LLMPredictStart template_args: {'context_str': "Source 1:\nHowever, when it comes to biodiversity <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-06-08/how-biodiversity-hopes-to-match-climate-s-investing-quicktake> — climate’s broader sister topic <https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2022-12-09/climate-change-versus-biodiversity-there-can-be-only-one> — bankers appear to be less certain <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-08-17/banks-largely-blind-to-portfolio-risk-posed-by-nature-loss>. In private conversations, financiers from some of the biggest banks in Europe and the US (as well as a major Canadian lender) told Bloomberg Green they’re at a loss about what to do with biodiversity.\n\nIt’s not that they’re ignorant of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems. It’s just that they don’t understand how to measure its impact on their operations—or how to make money from it.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/europe/2024/10/17/bankers-biodiversity-climate-change-measure/\n\nSource 1:\nA year later, world leaders agreed to protect and restore <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-12-19/cop15-adopts-biodiversity-plan-to-protect-30-of-land-and-water-by-2030> 30% of the Earth’s land and oceans by 2030. The goal rallied investors around a new catchphrase called “nature positive,” which refers to the idea of stopping and eventually reversing biodiversity loss. It’s the new “net zero,” only for biodiversity. \n\nTwo years on, it’s become apparent to the bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to that nature is vastly more complex than climate. While climate impacts can be boiled down to a single metric that can be measured, priced and traded — greenhouse gas emissions — there’s no simple or comparable way to measure changes in biodiversity across different geographies and ecosystems.\n\nIn other words, it’s not clear <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-06-08/how-biodiversity-hopes-to-match-climate-s-investing-quicktake> how the market should value a swamp or a newly discovered frog species. And what does “nature-positive” finance even look like?\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/europe/2024/10/17/bankers-biodiversity-climate-change-measure/\n\nSource 1:\nNext week <https://www.cbd.int/conferences/2024>, world leaders will gather for the United Nations biodiversity summit, known as COP16, where participants will discuss progress made on targets they agreed to in 2022. And even with the challenges of monetizing nature, banks including JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Standard Chartered Plc are sending representatives in the hope that biodiversity can be a source of new deals.\n\nSustainable finance in brief\nSustainable finance in brief\n\nThe European Central Bank has stepped up its efforts to prepare lenders for the fallout from climate change by warning they face even more fines if they don’t sufficiently address the risks ahead. A “small group of outliers” faces periodic penalty payments after the ECB found that they’re still missing “foundational elements for the adequate management of climate and nature-related risks,” said Frank Elderson, a member of ECB’s Executive Board. The ECB has steadily ramped up pressure on banks to ensure they can contend with losses resulting from extreme weather or carbon-intensive companies having difficulty paying back loans. While many banks say they’re working on the issue, the watchdog’s tough approach has been a key source of friction with the industry <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2024-10-04/ecb-warns-banks-of-yet-more-fines-over-climate-risk-management?sref=Ufko9ynM>.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/europe/2024/10/17/bankers-biodiversity-climate-change-measure/\n\nSource 1:\nNo one knows what to do, said a senior banker at a major US lender, who asked not to be identified for expressing opinions that may differ from those of their employer. As such, the bank’s work on nature has stalled, the banker said.\n\nWhile quantifying climate-related risks and aligning portfolios accordingly has been a multi-year effort for everyone from standard setters to finance executives, biodiversity was adopted into sustainability teams’ remit on a much more accelerated timeline <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-12-15/why-is-wall-street-so-hot-for-biodiversity-right-now>.\n\nThe launch <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-03/biodiversity-disclosures-set-to-become-part-of-company-reporting> of the Taskforce on Nature-Related Financial Disclosures in 2021, which asks companies to report their biodiversity footprint, was a key moment in elevating the nature agenda.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/europe/2024/10/17/bankers-biodiversity-climate-change-measure/\n\nSource 2:\nMake no mistake: If we lose the Congo Basin forests, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years. We would also lose the water, the lifeblood of Africa that is pumped out of its green heart—and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades. \n\nPut simply, Africa is not viable without the Congo Basin forests—or at least that is the indication of the scant evidence that exists.\n\nIn my new role as the Special Envoy of the Science Panel for the Congo Basin (SPCB), it is my duty to sound the alarm. We must build more bridges between scientists, donors, and policy makers. The SPCB, along with our sister initiative, the Science Initiative for the Congo Basin, need your support and investment. If our world is to remain ecologically stable, we have to better understand and preserve this critical ecosystem, which is home to 80 million people and supports life for a further 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/09/24/earth-second-lung-threat-losing-congo-basin-forests-climate-change-environment/\n\nSource 2:\nThanks to AFRITRON, a network of permanent botanical plots initiated by Professor Simon Lewis at the University of Leeds in the U.K., and a few key long-term sites such as Lopé, Epulu, Kibale, and Budongo, where stubborn researchers have plugged away over decades despite the general lack of interest, we do have some indications of the importance of the Congo Basin as a carbon sink. Indeed, while it is only one-third the area of the Amazon, the Congo Basin contains roughly 40% the carbon stock <https://www.researchgate.net/publication/361765603_Mapping_peat_thickness_and_carbon_stocks_of_the_central_Congo_Basin_using_field_data> and its forests are proving more resilient to climate change than the southern Amazon. Today, they represent a much larger carbon sink, despite their smaller size.\n\nIncomplete, fragmented, or preliminary studies suggest that the ecosystem services provided by the Congo basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, generating the rainfall that fills the Blue Nile and irrigates Egypt, are critical to African and global stability.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/09/24/earth-second-lung-threat-losing-congo-basin-forests-climate-change-environment/\n\nSource 2:\nThe depth of understanding we need will not come from developed nation researchers studying satellite images taken from afar. We need Congo Basin scientists, on the ground, in the forest, learning from indigenous people and piecing together the complex interactions between plants, animals, people, climate, hydrology, and geology. \n\nWe are inspired by and looking to learn from and develop strong links with the Science Panel for the Amazon. By the time the SCPB touches down at COP30, the rainforest COP, which will be held in Belem in 2025, our first assessment report will be ready.\n\nWith the world's lungs under existential threat, we must mobilize to create lasting change.\n\n\n\nMore must-read commentary published by Fortune:\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/09/24/earth-second-lung-threat-losing-congo-basin-forests-climate-change-environment/\n\nSource 3:\nIn addition to being a source of intuition for making decisions, your gut is the system in charge of your digestion. The health of that digestion—as well as other things like mood and immunity—depends heavily on a teeming microflora of both beneficial and harmful bacteria that live in the lining of your GI tract <https://www.nm.org/healthbeat/healthy-tips/7-reasons-to-listen-to-your-gut>.\n\nBacteria often get a bad rap as germs that cause sickness. But some bacteria and yeasts provide you with a health boon instead of a bane. The goal is to keep the scales tipped in favor of these “good” bacteria.\n\nTo do that, you need a diet rich in both probiotics <https://fortune.com/recommends/health/best-probiotics/> and prebiotics <https://fortune.com/recommends/health/best-prebiotics/>. Here’s why.\n\nPrebiotics and probiotics: a superduo\n\nProbiotics are good bacteria. They’re live microorganisms (bacteria and yeasts) that naturally live in your body and have a positive effect on health. But you can also get them from certain foods and supplements.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/23/probiotics-prebiotics-for-gut-health-how-to-get-both/\n\nSource 3:\nWhy bacteria balance matters\n\nGood bacteria help prevent the overgrowth of pathogens that can trigger inflammation in your body. When your bacteria balance is off, it means you have fewer of the bacteria that help you metabolize specific nutrients and absorb vitamins and minerals. With enough good bacteria, you digest foods easily and regularly, and get optimum nutrition from the foods you eat.\n\nBut good gut health <https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/10/bacteria-gut-microbiome-linked-to-chronic-disease-nutrients-they-need/> gives you more than just smooth digestion. According to a 2020 review published in BMJ Nutrition, Prevention & Health <https://www.bmj.com/company/newsroom/probiotics-alone-or-combined-with-prebiotics-may-help-ease-depression/>, having a rich supply of probiotics and prebiotics may relieve symptoms of depression. Other research shows it can also boost immunity <https://www.karger.com/Article/FullText/496426>, increasing the production of certain antibodies.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/23/probiotics-prebiotics-for-gut-health-how-to-get-both/\n\nSource 3:\nIn contrast, prebiotics aren’t alive. They’re a form of dietary fiber humans can’t digest that acts as food for friendly bacteria. You get them from high-fiber, plant-based foods <https://health.umms.org/2022/03/04/prebiotics-probiotics>.\n\n“They’re like the fuel,” says Amy Bragagnini, RD, national spokesperson for the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics. “It’s basically a fiber that is able to resist the acidity of the GI tract. It doesn't break down as it goes through your system, and feeds the healthy microbes in our microbiome.”\n\nBragagnini says that even though comparatively, probiotics do the lion's share of the work of good digestion, prebiotics are the sustenance that make it last.\n\n“Technically, you could probably get away with just having probiotics, and you would see some benefit,” she says. “However, to make a lasting, sustainable microbiome, you need a balance of both.”\n\nWhy bacteria balance matters\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/23/probiotics-prebiotics-for-gut-health-how-to-get-both/\n\nSource 4:\nHumans are a social species. We have an innate need to form and maintain positive relationships. The more we fulfill this need, the more physically and mentally healthy we are. In the context of the workplace, positive relationships with colleagues and supervisors don't just lead to greater happiness but also to increased creativity, cooperation, and productivity. At a time when there is growing concern about loneliness, social distrust, and political polarization in society, it's encouraging that Americans are positive about their relationships at work.\n\nOf course, we are not just a social species—we are also an existential one. Just as we have a strong motivation to find and maintain interpersonal relationships, we have an equally powerful drive to perceive our lives as full of meaning. In fact, these two needs are connected. We feel the most meaningful when we are making a positive difference in the lives of others. And, like social belonging, meaning in life plays a central role in our well-being. When individuals have a strong sense of purpose, they are less vulnerable to mental health problems like depression, anxiety, and addiction. They also tend to be more physically healthy and more successful at accomplishing their goals.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/07/04/9-10-american-workers-thriving-dominant-narrative-widespread-misery-work-careers/\n\nSource 5:\nThat gap is particularly problematic as the planet warms. Oceans provide services that scientists call “existentially important <https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmars.2019.00470/full>,” producing more than half of the oxygen we breathe <https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/ocean-oxygen.html> and serving as the world’s largest carbon sink <https://www.un.org/en/climatechange/science/climate-issues/ocean#:~:text=As%20the%20planet's%20greatest%20carbon,trapped%20in%20the%20Earth's%20system.>. They also absorb 30% of our carbon emissions <https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.aau5153> and 90% of the excess heat generated by them <https://www.ipcc.ch/srocc/chapter/summary-for-policymakers/>.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/06/30/superyachts-scientists-ocean-research-climate-change-environment-noaa-fleet/"}

Also, try to make use of at least three sources.\n\nIf the answer to a question is not present in the sources or the conversation you will truthfully say you don't know the answer. Be careful to avoid using the word 'Source' when citing your sources. That is, never cite a source using format 'Source n', but rather use '[n]'.\n\nHere is an example of how to cite sources:\n\nSource 1:\nThe sky is red in the evening and blue in the morning.\n\nSource 2:\nWater is wet when the sky is red.\n\nQuestion: When is water wet?\n\nAnswer with citations: Water will be wet when the sky is red [2], which occurs in the evening [1].\n\nOkay, now your set of sources for answering the user query follow:\n\n{context_str}\nOnly make statements you can support from the sources provided or information provided by the human. It doesn't break down as it goes through your system, and feeds the healthy microbes in our microbiome.”\n\nBragagnini says that even though comparatively, probiotics do the lion's share of the work of good digestion, prebiotics are the sustenance that make it last.\n\n“Technically, you could probably get away with just having probiotics, and you would see some benefit,” she says. “However, to make a lasting, sustainable microbiome, you need a balance of both.”\n\nWhy bacteria balance matters\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/23/probiotics-prebiotics-for-gut-health-how-to-get-both/\n\nSource 4:\nHumans are a social species. We have an innate need to form and maintain positive relationships. The more we fulfill this need, the more physically and mentally healthy we are. In the context of the workplace, positive relationships with colleagues and supervisors don't just lead to greater happiness but also to increased creativity, cooperation, and productivity. At a time when there is growing concern about loneliness, social distrust, and political polarization in society, it's encouraging that Americans are positive about their relationships at work.\n\nOf course, we are not just a social species—we are also an existential one. Just as we have a strong motivation to find and maintain interpersonal relationships, we have an equally powerful drive to perceive our lives as full of meaning. In fact, these two needs are connected. We feel the most meaningful when we are making a positive difference in the lives of others. And, like social belonging, meaning in life plays a central role in our well-being. When individuals have a strong sense of purpose, they are less vulnerable to mental health problems like depression, anxiety, and addiction. They also tend to be more physically healthy and more successful at accomplishing their goals.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/07/04/9-10-american-workers-thriving-dominant-narrative-widespread-misery-work-careers/\n\nSource 5:\nThat gap is particularly problematic as the planet warms. Oceans provide services that scientists call “existentially important <https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmars.2019.00470/full>,” producing more than half of the oxygen we breathe <https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/ocean-oxygen.html> and serving as the world’s largest carbon sink <https://www.un.org/en/climatechange/science/climate-issues/ocean#:~:text=As%20the%20planet's%20greatest%20carbon,trapped%20in%20the%20Earth's%20system.>. They also absorb 30% of our carbon emissions <https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.aau5153> and 90% of the excess heat generated by them <https://www.ipcc.ch/srocc/chapter/summary-for-policymakers/>.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/06/30/superyachts-scientists-ocean-research-climate-change-environment-noaa-fleet/"}

2024-11-08 06:44:24,755: ObserveEventsHandler(  179): MEASUREMENT: LLMPredictStart template_args: {'context_str': "Source 1:\nHowever, when it comes to biodiversity <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-06-08/how-biodiversity-hopes-to-match-climate-s-investing-quicktake> — climate’s broader sister topic <https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2022-12-09/climate-change-versus-biodiversity-there-can-be-only-one> — bankers appear to be less certain <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-08-17/banks-largely-blind-to-portfolio-risk-posed-by-nature-loss>. In private conversations, financiers from some of the biggest banks in Europe and the US (as well as a major Canadian lender) told Bloomberg Green they’re at a loss about what to do with biodiversity.\n\nIt’s not that they’re ignorant of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems. It’s just that they don’t understand how to measure its impact on their operations—or how to make money from it.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/europe/2024/10/17/bankers-biodiversity-climate-change-measure/\n\nSource 1:\nA year later, world leaders agreed to protect and restore <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-12-19/cop15-adopts-biodiversity-plan-to-protect-30-of-land-and-water-by-2030> 30% of the Earth’s land and oceans by 2030. The goal rallied investors around a new catchphrase called “nature positive,” which refers to the idea of stopping and eventually reversing biodiversity loss. It’s the new “net zero,” only for biodiversity. \n\nTwo years on, it’s become apparent to the bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to that nature is vastly more complex than climate. While climate impacts can be boiled down to a single metric that can be measured, priced and traded — greenhouse gas emissions — there’s no simple or comparable way to measure changes in biodiversity across different geographies and ecosystems.\n\nIn other words, it’s not clear <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-06-08/how-biodiversity-hopes-to-match-climate-s-investing-quicktake> how the market should value a swamp or a newly discovered frog species. And what does “nature-positive” finance even look like?\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/europe/2024/10/17/bankers-biodiversity-climate-change-measure/\n\nSource 1:\nNext week <https://www.cbd.int/conferences/2024>, world leaders will gather for the United Nations biodiversity summit, known as COP16, where participants will discuss progress made on targets they agreed to in 2022. And even with the challenges of monetizing nature, banks including JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Standard Chartered Plc are sending representatives in the hope that biodiversity can be a source of new deals.\n\nSustainable finance in brief\nSustainable finance in brief\n\nThe European Central Bank has stepped up its efforts to prepare lenders for the fallout from climate change by warning they face even more fines if they don’t sufficiently address the risks ahead. A “small group of outliers” faces periodic penalty payments after the ECB found that they’re still missing “foundational elements for the adequate management of climate and nature-related risks,” said Frank Elderson, a member of ECB’s Executive Board. The ECB has steadily ramped up pressure on banks to ensure they can contend with losses resulting from extreme weather or carbon-intensive companies having difficulty paying back loans. While many banks say they’re working on the issue, the watchdog’s tough approach has been a key source of friction with the industry <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2024-10-04/ecb-warns-banks-of-yet-more-fines-over-climate-risk-management?sref=Ufko9ynM>.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/europe/2024/10/17/bankers-biodiversity-climate-change-measure/\n\nSource 1:\nNo one knows what to do, said a senior banker at a major US lender, who asked not to be identified for expressing opinions that may differ from those of their employer. As such, the bank’s work on nature has stalled, the banker said.\n\nWhile quantifying climate-related risks and aligning portfolios accordingly has been a multi-year effort for everyone from standard setters to finance executives, biodiversity was adopted into sustainability teams’ remit on a much more accelerated timeline <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-12-15/why-is-wall-street-so-hot-for-biodiversity-right-now>.\n\nThe launch <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-03/biodiversity-disclosures-set-to-become-part-of-company-reporting> of the Taskforce on Nature-Related Financial Disclosures in 2021, which asks companies to report their biodiversity footprint, was a key moment in elevating the nature agenda.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/europe/2024/10/17/bankers-biodiversity-climate-change-measure/\n\nSource 2:\nMake no mistake: If we lose the Congo Basin forests, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years. We would also lose the water, the lifeblood of Africa that is pumped out of its green heart—and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades. \n\nPut simply, Africa is not viable without the Congo Basin forests—or at least that is the indication of the scant evidence that exists.\n\nIn my new role as the Special Envoy of the Science Panel for the Congo Basin (SPCB), it is my duty to sound the alarm. We must build more bridges between scientists, donors, and policy makers. The SPCB, along with our sister initiative, the Science Initiative for the Congo Basin, need your support and investment. If our world is to remain ecologically stable, we have to better understand and preserve this critical ecosystem, which is home to 80 million people and supports life for a further 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/09/24/earth-second-lung-threat-losing-congo-basin-forests-climate-change-environment/\n\nSource 2:\nThanks to AFRITRON, a network of permanent botanical plots initiated by Professor Simon Lewis at the University of Leeds in the U.K., and a few key long-term sites such as Lopé, Epulu, Kibale, and Budongo, where stubborn researchers have plugged away over decades despite the general lack of interest, we do have some indications of the importance of the Congo Basin as a carbon sink. Indeed, while it is only one-third the area of the Amazon, the Congo Basin contains roughly 40% the carbon stock <https://www.researchgate.net/publication/361765603_Mapping_peat_thickness_and_carbon_stocks_of_the_central_Congo_Basin_using_field_data> and its forests are proving more resilient to climate change than the southern Amazon. Today, they represent a much larger carbon sink, despite their smaller size.\n\nIncomplete, fragmented, or preliminary studies suggest that the ecosystem services provided by the Congo basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, generating the rainfall that fills the Blue Nile and irrigates Egypt, are critical to African and global stability.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/09/24/earth-second-lung-threat-losing-congo-basin-forests-climate-change-environment/\n\nSource 2:\nThe depth of understanding we need will not come from developed nation researchers studying satellite images taken from afar. We need Congo Basin scientists, on the ground, in the forest, learning from indigenous people and piecing together the complex interactions between plants, animals, people, climate, hydrology, and geology. \n\nWe are inspired by and looking to learn from and develop strong links with the Science Panel for the Amazon. By the time the SCPB touches down at COP30, the rainforest COP, which will be held in Belem in 2025, our first assessment report will be ready.\n\nWith the world's lungs under existential threat, we must mobilize to create lasting change.\n\n\n\nMore must-read commentary published by Fortune:\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/09/24/earth-second-lung-threat-losing-congo-basin-forests-climate-change-environment/\n\nSource 3:\nIn addition to being a source of intuition for making decisions, your gut is the system in charge of your digestion. The health of that digestion—as well as other things like mood and immunity—depends heavily on a teeming microflora of both beneficial and harmful bacteria that live in the lining of your GI tract <https://www.nm.org/healthbeat/healthy-tips/7-reasons-to-listen-to-your-gut>.\n\nBacteria often get a bad rap as germs that cause sickness. But some bacteria and yeasts provide you with a health boon instead of a bane. The goal is to keep the scales tipped in favor of these “good” bacteria.\n\nTo do that, you need a diet rich in both probiotics <https://fortune.com/recommends/health/best-probiotics/> and prebiotics <https://fortune.com/recommends/health/best-prebiotics/>. Here’s why.\n\nPrebiotics and probiotics: a superduo\n\nProbiotics are good bacteria. They’re live microorganisms (bacteria and yeasts) that naturally live in your body and have a positive effect on health. But you can also get them from certain foods and supplements.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/23/probiotics-prebiotics-for-gut-health-how-to-get-both/\n\nSource 3:\nWhy bacteria balance matters\n\nGood bacteria help prevent the overgrowth of pathogens that can trigger inflammation in your body. When your bacteria balance is off, it means you have fewer of the bacteria that help you metabolize specific nutrients and absorb vitamins and minerals. With enough good bacteria, you digest foods easily and regularly, and get optimum nutrition from the foods you eat.\n\nBut good gut health <https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/10/bacteria-gut-microbiome-linked-to-chronic-disease-nutrients-they-need/> gives you more than just smooth digestion. According to a 2020 review published in BMJ Nutrition, Prevention & Health <https://www.bmj.com/company/newsroom/probiotics-alone-or-combined-with-prebiotics-may-help-ease-depression/>, having a rich supply of probiotics and prebiotics may relieve symptoms of depression. Other research shows it can also boost immunity <https://www.karger.com/Article/FullText/496426>, increasing the production of certain antibodies.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/23/probiotics-prebiotics-for-gut-health-how-to-get-both/\n\nSource 3:\nIn contrast, prebiotics aren’t alive. They’re a form of dietary fiber humans can’t digest that acts as food for friendly bacteria. You get them from high-fiber, plant-based foods <https://health.umms.org/2022/03/04/prebiotics-probiotics>.\n\n“They’re like the fuel,” says Amy Bragagnini, RD, national spokesperson for the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics. “It’s basically a fiber that is able to resist the acidity of the GI tract. It doesn't break down as it goes through your system, and feeds the healthy microbes in our microbiome.”\n\nBragagnini says that even though comparatively, probiotics do the lion's share of the work of good digestion, prebiotics are the sustenance that make it last.\n\n“Technically, you could probably get away with just having probiotics, and you would see some benefit,” she says. “However, to make a lasting, sustainable microbiome, you need a balance of both.”\n\nWhy bacteria balance matters\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/23/probiotics-prebiotics-for-gut-health-how-to-get-both/\n\nSource 4:\nHumans are a social species. We have an innate need to form and maintain positive relationships. The more we fulfill this need, the more physically and mentally healthy we are. In the context of the workplace, positive relationships with colleagues and supervisors don't just lead to greater happiness but also to increased creativity, cooperation, and productivity. At a time when there is growing concern about loneliness, social distrust, and political polarization in society, it's encouraging that Americans are positive about their relationships at work.\n\nOf course, we are not just a social species—we are also an existential one. Just as we have a strong motivation to find and maintain interpersonal relationships, we have an equally powerful drive to perceive our lives as full of meaning. In fact, these two needs are connected. We feel the most meaningful when we are making a positive difference in the lives of others. And, like social belonging, meaning in life plays a central role in our well-being. When individuals have a strong sense of purpose, they are less vulnerable to mental health problems like depression, anxiety, and addiction. They also tend to be more physically healthy and more successful at accomplishing their goals.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/07/04/9-10-american-workers-thriving-dominant-narrative-widespread-misery-work-careers/\n\nSource 5:\nThat gap is particularly problematic as the planet warms. Oceans provide services that scientists call “existentially important <https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmars.2019.00470/full>,” producing more than half of the oxygen we breathe <https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/ocean-oxygen.html> and serving as the world’s largest carbon sink <https://www.un.org/en/climatechange/science/climate-issues/ocean#:~:text=As%20the%20planet's%20greatest%20carbon,trapped%20in%20the%20Earth's%20system.>. They also absorb 30% of our carbon emissions <https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.aau5153> and 90% of the excess heat generated by them <https://www.ipcc.ch/srocc/chapter/summary-for-policymakers/>.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/06/30/superyachts-scientists-ocean-research-climate-change-environment-noaa-fleet/"}

Here’s why.\n\nPrebiotics and probiotics: a superduo\n\nProbiotics are good bacteria. They’re live microorganisms (bacteria and yeasts) that naturally live in your body and have a positive effect on health. But you can also get them from certain foods and supplements.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/23/probiotics-prebiotics-for-gut-health-how-to-get-both/\n\nSource 3:\nWhy bacteria balance matters\n\nGood bacteria help prevent the overgrowth of pathogens that can trigger inflammation in your body. When your bacteria balance is off, it means you have fewer of the bacteria that help you metabolize specific nutrients and absorb vitamins and minerals. With enough good bacteria, you digest foods easily and regularly, and get optimum nutrition from the foods you eat.\n\nBut good gut health <https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/10/bacteria-gut-microbiome-linked-to-chronic-disease-nutrients-they-need/> gives you more than just smooth digestion. According to a 2020 review published in BMJ Nutrition, Prevention & Health <https://www.bmj.com/company/newsroom/probiotics-alone-or-combined-with-prebiotics-may-help-ease-depression/>, having a rich supply of probiotics and prebiotics may relieve symptoms of depression. Other research shows it can also boost immunity <https://www.karger.com/Article/FullText/496426>, increasing the production of certain antibodies.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/23/probiotics-prebiotics-for-gut-health-how-to-get-both/\n\nSource 3:\nIn contrast, prebiotics aren’t alive. They’re a form of dietary fiber humans can’t digest that acts as food for friendly bacteria. You get them from high-fiber, plant-based foods <https://health.umms.org/2022/03/04/prebiotics-probiotics>.\n\n“They’re like the fuel,” says Amy Bragagnini, RD, national spokesperson for the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics. “It’s basically a fiber that is able to resist the acidity of the GI tract. It doesn't break down as it goes through your system, and feeds the healthy microbes in our microbiome.”\n\nBragagnini says that even though comparatively, probiotics do the lion's share of the work of good digestion, prebiotics are the sustenance that make it last.\n\n“Technically, you could probably get away with just having probiotics, and you would see some benefit,” she says. “However, to make a lasting, sustainable microbiome, you need a balance of both.”\n\nWhy bacteria balance matters\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/well/2023/04/23/probiotics-prebiotics-for-gut-health-how-to-get-both/\n\nSource 4:\nHumans are a social species. We have an innate need to form and maintain positive relationships. The more we fulfill this need, the more physically and mentally healthy we are. In the context of the workplace, positive relationships with colleagues and supervisors don't just lead to greater happiness but also to increased creativity, cooperation, and productivity. At a time when there is growing concern about loneliness, social distrust, and political polarization in society, it's encouraging that Americans are positive about their relationships at work.\n\nOf course, we are not just a social species—we are also an existential one. Just as we have a strong motivation to find and maintain interpersonal relationships, we have an equally powerful drive to perceive our lives as full of meaning. In fact, these two needs are connected. We feel the most meaningful when we are making a positive difference in the lives of others. And, like social belonging, meaning in life plays a central role in our well-being. When individuals have a strong sense of purpose, they are less vulnerable to mental health problems like depression, anxiety, and addiction. They also tend to be more physically healthy and more successful at accomplishing their goals.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/07/04/9-10-american-workers-thriving-dominant-narrative-widespread-misery-work-careers/\n\nSource 5:\nThat gap is particularly problematic as the planet warms. Oceans provide services that scientists call “existentially important <https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmars.2019.00470/full>,” producing more than half of the oxygen we breathe <https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/ocean-oxygen.html> and serving as the world’s largest carbon sink <https://www.un.org/en/climatechange/science/climate-issues/ocean#:~:text=As%20the%20planet's%20greatest%20carbon,trapped%20in%20the%20Earth's%20system.>. They also absorb 30% of our carbon emissions <https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.aau5153> and 90% of the excess heat generated by them <https://www.ipcc.ch/srocc/chapter/summary-for-policymakers/>.\n\n\nurl: https://fortune.com/2024/06/30/superyachts-scientists-ocean-research-climate-change-environment-noaa-fleet/"}

2024-11-08 06:44:28,652: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel,

2024-11-08 06:44:28,949: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:44:28,950: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:28,950: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost

2024-11-08 06:44:29,969: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:29,969: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to

2024-11-08 06:44:29,989: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in

2024-11-08 06:44:30,087: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore,

2024-11-08 06:44:30,288: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:30,288: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the

2024-11-08 06:44:30,496: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as

2024-11-08 06:44:30,798: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers

2024-11-08 06:44:30,984: ObserveEventsHandler(  145): MEASUREMENT: Span: OpenAI.astream_chat-c2650823-343a-47cf-8e36-5c94c36ca596
2024-11-08 06:44:30,984: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:44:30,984: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:30,984: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns

If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to

2024-11-08 06:44:31,487: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:31,487: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1

2024-11-08 06:44:31,693: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:31,693: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

2024-11-08 06:44:32,306: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of

Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of ecosystems and the planet as a whole.
2024-11-08 06:44:32,321: ObserveEventsHandler(  236): MEASUREMENT: -----------------------
2024-11-08 06:44:32,321: ObserveEventsHandler(  141): MEASUREMENT: -----------------------
2024-11-08 06:44:32,322: ObserveEventsHandler(  143): MEASUREMENT: Event: 64fc2d47-0c05-4819-958e-dfdef8ea9f85
2024-11-08 06:44:32,322: ObserveEventsHandler(  144): MEASUREMENT: Timestamp: 2024-11-08 06:44:32.321785
2024-11-08 06:44:32,322: ObserveEventsHandler(  145): MEASUREMENT: Span: OpenAI.astream_chat-c2650823-343a-47cf-8e36-5c94c36ca596
2024-11-08 06:44:32,322: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:44:32,322: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:32,322: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of ecosystems and the planet as a whole. The Science

2024-11-08 06:44:32,341: ObserveEventsHandler(  145): MEASUREMENT: Span: OpenAI.astream_chat-c2650823-343a-47cf-8e36-5c94c36ca596
2024-11-08 06:44:32,341: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:44:32,341: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:32,341: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of ecosystems and the planet as a whole. The Science Panel for the Congo Basin (SPCB)

2024-11-08 06:44:32,519: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:44:32,519: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:32,519: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of ecosystems and the planet as a whole. The Science Panel for the Congo Basin (SPCB) is working to build bridges between scientists, donors

2024-11-08 06:44:32,797: ObserveEventsHandler(  145): MEASUREMENT: Span: OpenAI.astream_chat-c2650823-343a-47cf-8e36-5c94c36ca596
2024-11-08 06:44:32,797: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:44:32,797: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:32,797: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of ecosystems and the planet as a whole. The Science Panel for the Congo Basin (SPCB) is working to build bridges between scientists, donors, and policymakers to better understand and preserve the critical ecosystem of

If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of ecosystems and the planet as a whole. The Science Panel for the Congo Basin (SPCB) is working to build bridges between scientists, donors, and policymakers to better understand and preserve the critical ecosystem of the Congo Basin [2]. The S

2024-11-08 06:44:32,923: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:44:32,923: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:32,924: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of ecosystems and the planet as a whole. The Science Panel for the Congo Basin (SPCB) is working to build bridges between scientists, donors, and policymakers to better understand and preserve the critical ecosystem of the Congo Basin [2]. 2024-11-08 06:44:33,051: ObserveEventsHandler(  145): MEASUREMENT: Span: OpenAI.astream_chat-c2650823-343a-47cf-8e36-5c94c36ca596
2024-11-08 06:44:33,051: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:44:33,051: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:33,052: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of ecosystems and the planet as a whole. The Science Panel for the Congo Basin (SPCB) is working to build bridges between scientists, donors, and policymakers to better understand and preserve the critical ecosystem of the Congo Basin [2]. The SPCB aims to mobilize support and investment to

The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

2024-11-08 06:44:33,221: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of ecosystems and the planet as a whole. The Science Panel for the Congo Basin (SPCB) is working to build bridges between scientists, donors, and policymakers to better understand and preserve the critical ecosystem of the Congo Basin [2]. The SPCB aims to mobilize support and investment to create lasting change and ensure the long-term health of the planet

2024-11-08 06:44:33,222: ObserveEventsHandler(  148): MEASUREMENT: Event type: LLMChatInProgressEvent
2024-11-08 06:44:33,222: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:33,222: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of ecosystems and the planet as a whole. The Science Panel for the Congo Basin (SPCB) is working to build bridges between scientists, donors, and policymakers to better understand and preserve the critical ecosystem of the Congo Basin [2]. The SPCB aims to mobilize support and investment to create lasting change and ensure the long-term health of the planet

2024-11-08 06:44:33,458: ObserveEventsHandler(  197): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress messages: Why is biodiversity crucial for the planet's health?

2024-11-08 06:44:33,458: ObserveEventsHandler(  198): MEASUREMENT: LLMChatInProgress response: assistant: Biodiversity is crucial for the planet's health because it provides numerous ecosystem services that support life on Earth. The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. Additionally, the ecosystem services provided by the Congo Basin forests, such as the cooling effect of transpiration from their leaves and the atmospheric rivers that flow to the Ethiopian Highlands and the Sahel, are critical to African and global stability [2].

The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of ecosystems and the planet as a whole. The Science Panel for the Congo Basin (SPCB) is working to build bridges between scientists, donors, and policymakers to better understand and preserve the critical ecosystem of the Congo Basin [2]. The SPCB aims to mobilize support and investment to create lasting change and ensure the long-term health of the planet [2]. By preserving biodiversity, we can maintain the essential

The Congo Basin forests, for example, are a critical ecosystem that supports life for 300 million rural Africans in surrounding regions [2]. The forests also play a crucial role in regulating the climate, with the Congo Basin containing roughly 40% of the carbon stock of the Amazon, despite being only one-third the size [2]. The loss of biodiversity can have severe consequences for the planet's health. If the Congo Basin forests are lost, the global fight against climate change will be set back by 15 to 20 years, and the consequences will be counted in hundreds of millions of climate refugees in the coming decades [2]. Furthermore, the extinction of species can disrupt the delicate balance of ecosystems, leading to the loss of essential services such as pollination, pest control, and nutrient cycling [1]. The bankers Bloomberg Green spoke to are aware of the threat to human life and economic output posed by mass extinctions or breakdowns of natural systems, but they are struggling to understand how to measure the impact of biodiversity loss on their operations [1].

The preservation of biodiversity is essential for maintaining the health of ecosystems and the planet as a whole. The Science Panel for the Congo Basin (SPCB) is working to build bridges between scientists, donors, and policymakers to better understand and preserve the critical ecosystem of the Congo Basin [2]. The SPCB aims to mobilize support and investment to create lasting change and ensure the long-term health of the planet [2].
